Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the level of support for Johnson-Weld in the presidential debates by stating that 76 percent of all voters in the United States want them in the debates, when in reality the poll only sampled 1,000 likely voters.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misstating key details, such as saying that voters wanted the ticket "by name" when the poll question was different, and by stating that the poll sampled "all voters" when it actually sampled likely voters.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only relies on one poll conducted by Suffolk University, and there are other polls with lower figures for Johnson-Weld's support.
Problematic assumption: There is no evidence of a problematic assumption bias in the provided claim.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no evidence of an alternative explanation bias in the provided claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that no third-party candidate is currently on track to meet the 15 percent support requirement set by the nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates.
